questions.text: A 2-year-old child’s father brought him for checkup. On examination, there was white pupillary reflex. USG findings shows intraocular mass with calcification in the eye. There is a family history of enucleation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma should be suspected in young children presenting with leukocoria, intraocular mass with calcification, and a family history of eye-related surgeries or enucleation. It is a primary intraocular malignancy that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PG analogues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostaglandin analogues (such as latanoprost and bimatoprost) are the first-line treatment for primary open-angle glaucoma in adults, as they effectively reduce intraocular pressure with minimal side effects and convenient once-daily dosing .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in children is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, Vitamin A deficiency is the leading cause of childhood blindness.
  • ➤ while worldwide, congenital cataract is the most common cause of blindness in children.

questions.text: The given image pupil occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Iridodialysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A D-shaped pupil is characteristic of iridodialysis, which results from a tear at the root of the iris, often due to trauma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe pain and swelling around his left eye after a recent accident while playing sports. Upon further inquiry, he reveals that he was struck directly on the eye with a fast-moving object. Considering the mechanism of injury described, which of the following is not typically associated with blowout fractures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ExophthalmosAns. A) Exophthalmos

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exophthalmos is not typically associated with orbital blowout fractures. Common signs and symptoms include diplopia, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and the tear drop sign on imaging studies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with history of recurrent headache was sent for fundus evaluation. He was found to be having generalised arteriolar attenuation with multiple cotton wool spots and flame shaped haemorrhages in both eyes as shown in the picture given.The most likely cause is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypertensive retinopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertensive retinopathy is characterized by generalized arteriolar attenuation, cotton wool spots, flame-shaped hemorrhages, and, in advanced cases, copper and silver wiring of the arterioles. Recurrent headaches may also accompany chronic hypertension.

questions.text: In retinal detachment, fluid accumulates between:

options.label: A
options.text: Outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer.

options.label: B
options.text: Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve fiber layer and rest of retina.

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.

questions.correct_answer: B. Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In retinal detachment, fluid accumulates specifically between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.text: Earliest visual rehabilitation occurs with:

options.label: B
options.text: Intracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

options.label: C
options.text: Extracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.correct_answer: A. Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation allows for the earliest visual rehabilitation due to the small incision size, minimal trauma, and quick wound healing.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female of thin stature, presented to the OPD with redness, irritation and watering in both eyes for the past 1 month. She had a history of loss of appetite & weight. Examination showed a pinkish white nodule with ulcerated apex at the limbus. What would be the investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mantoux test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mantoux test is the investigation of choice for suspected tuberculosis-related ocular manifestations, such as phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.text: Ptosis in Horner's syndrome, is due to paralysis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muller's muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller's muscle, which is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: 3 months old infant with watering lacrimal sac on pressing causes regurgitation of mucopus material. What is the appropriate treatment?

options.label: D
options.text: Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For infants under 6 months with nasolacrimal duct obstruction, the appropriate initial treatment is massage of the lacrimal sac combined with antibiotics to manage any infection.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back. Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neovascular glaucoma (NVG)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neovascular glaucoma is often associated with ischemic retinal events, such as central retinal vein occlusion, and can manifest with rubeosis iridis and significantly elevated intraocular pressure a few months after the initial event.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Limbus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Palisades of Vogt, located at the limbus, contain the stem cells essential for corneal epithelial regeneration following superficial injury.

questions.text: In concomitant squint:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary deviation = Secondary deviation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In concomitant squint, primary and secondary deviations are equal due to the absence of any muscle paralysis or mechanical restriction, resulting in a consistent deviation regardless of which eye is used to fixate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with watering from his left eye since one year. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system. Rest of ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Confirmation of the diagnosis would be by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dacryoscintigraphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dacryoscintigraphy is the preferred diagnostic method for confirming lacrimal pump failure, as it provides functional information on tear flow through the lacrimal drainage system.

questions.text: A cataract surgeon noticed zonular dehiscence in a patient preoperatively of less than 2 clock hours. What precaution can be taken during surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capsular tension rings (CTR)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cataract surgery, capsular tension rings (CTR) are used to stabilize the lens capsule in cases of mild zonular dehiscence, ensuring safer surgery and reducing the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 2 year old child is found to have ptosis of one eye with defective elevation of the eye. Opening the mouth causes elevation of the ptotic lid. The most likely clinical condition is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Congenital ptosis with phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marcus Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon is a congenital condition characterized by ptosis with involuntary eyelid elevation upon jaw movement, due to aberrant connections between the third and fifth cranial nerves.

questions.text: Neonatal conjunctivitis is caused by all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspergillus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neonatal conjunctivitis is commonly caused by Gonococcus and Chlamydia ; Aspergillus is not typically associated with this condition.
  • ➤ Gonococcus
  • ➤ Chlamydia
  • ➤ Aspergillus

questions.text: Mydriasis is present in all the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pontine haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pontine haemorrhage typically presents with pinpoint pupils, while other causes listed are associated with mydriasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common ocular presentation of Marfan's Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Subluxation of lens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common ocular manifestation of Marfan's Syndrome is lens subluxation , which often presents as an upward and outward displacement of the lens.
  • ➤ most common ocular manifestation of Marfan's Syndrome is lens subluxation

questions.text: Identify the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trabeculectomy Bleb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A trabeculectomy bleb is a fluid-filled elevation under the conjunctiva created post-glaucoma surgery, often identified by its translucent appearance and associated iridectomy.

questions.text: What is incorrect about this lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Consist of head, neck, and body

options.label: B
options.text: Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

questions.correct_answer: B. Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Simple excision of a pterygium does not reduce recurrence by 90-95%; additional procedures, like autografting, are required for effective long-term results.

questions.text: Steroids are contraindicated in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dendritic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steroids are contraindicated in dendritic ulcers due to the risk of worsening a herpes simplex virus infection, which can lead to severe corneal damage.

questions.text: Which is not a clinical feature of right sided VIth nerve palsy:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Face turn to left

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In right-sided VIth nerve palsy, the patient typically turns their face to the right to compensate for the eye misalignment, not to the left.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of severe itching, redness, and photophobia in both eyes for the past few weeks. He mentions that his symptoms worsen during the spring and summer months. The patient denies any history of contact lens wear or recent eye trauma. His visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes, and intraocular pressure is within normal limits. Given the clinical presentation which of the following findings you would expect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trantas spots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trantas's spots are a characteristic finding in vernal conjunctivitis, a seasonal allergic condition that often affects young males and worsens during spring and summer.

questions.text: Keratometer is used to assess:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Curvature of cornea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A keratometer is primarily used to measure the curvature of the cornea , which is essential for assessing corneal shape and fitting contact lenses.

questions.text: The following ocular structure is not derived from surface ectoderm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sclera

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sclera is derived from neural crest cells, unlike other ocular structures such as the crystalline lens, corneal epithelium, and epithelium of the lacrimal glands, which originate from surface ectoderm.

questions.text: For transplantation cornea is preserved in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corneal tissue for transplantation can be preserved in Modified MK Medium, Cryopreservation, or Dexol Medium, depending on the required duration and storage conditions.

questions.text: True about telecanthus is:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance

options.label: B
options.text: Widely separated medial wall of orbits

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intercanthal distance with increased interpupillary distance

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telecanthus is defined by an increased intercanthal distance with a normal interpupillary distance, distinguishing it from hypertelorism, which involves both increased intercanthal and interorbital distances.

questions.text: The action of superior rectus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Elevation, intorsion, adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior rectus muscle's actions are elevation, intorsion, and adduction. Remembering that superior muscles are intorters ( "SIN" ) and recti muscles are adductors can help in recalling these actions.
  • ➤ "SIN"

questions.text: The best treatment for amblyopia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Occlusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best treatment for amblyopia is occlusion (patching) therapy, which should ideally begin early in childhood for optimal results.

questions.text: A patient of old standing diabetes mellitus noticed sudden muscae volitanes. On examination, the red reflex was dim, with no details of fundus could be seen. He might have:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitreous hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden floaters, a dim red reflex, and inability to view the fundus in a diabetic patient indicate vitreous hemorrhage, likely secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Best site where intraocular lens is fitted:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capsular bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best site for intraocular lens (IOL) placement is the capsular bag , as it provides optimal positioning, stability, and visual outcomes.
  • ➤ capsular bag

questions.text: A young 23-year-old black man presents with the clinical picture shown in the right eye after blunt injury. All of the following are acceptable initial treatments except?
questions.correct_answer: D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor pressure drops
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor pressure drops

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors should be avoided in hyphema management, particularly in patients with a risk of sickle cell disease, as they can increase sickling of red blood cells and worsen the condition.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of seeing "spots" floating around in her right eye. Today, she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a "shadow" in her peripheral vision that moves when looking up and down. Her medical history is significant for migraine headaches; however, she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinal detachment often presents with symptoms such as floaters, flashes of light, and a peripheral "shadow" or "curtain" effect. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. She had an upper respiratory infection a week ago after which she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches and a purulent nasal discharge. She took antibiotics for her respiratory tract infection but did not complete the course. She has asthma treated with Theophylline and inhaled beta-adrenergic agonist and corticosteroids. She appears to be in severe distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C pulse is 100/min and BP is 130/80 mmHg. Ophthalmic examination of the right eye, shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. The left eye shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000 per millimetre cube. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Edema, erythema and tenderness of the eyelids

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pain with eye movements

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pain with eye movements, in combination with proptosis and restricted eye movement, is a strong indicator of orbital cellulitis, necessitating prompt treatment with intravenous antibiotics to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man with recent onset of headache and fatigue presents to the emergency department with sudden vision loss. Examination reveals a visual acuity of "light perception only" in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. An afferent pupillary defect (Marcus Gunn pupil) is seen in the right eye. Examination by direct ophthalmoscope reveals a diffusely appearing pale retina except for a bright red spot in the fovea. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured intracranial aneurysm

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Central retinal artery occlusion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central retinal artery occlusion presents with sudden, painless vision loss, a pale retina, and a cherry-red spot in the fovea. This condition requires urgent management due to the risk of permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient was brought to the emergency with a history of tennis ball hit to the eyeball. On examination, he was found to have hyphema. What is the source of bleed in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Major arterial circle of iris
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Major arterial circle of iris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of traumatic hyphema, the source of bleeding is typically the major arterial circle of the iris, which supplies blood to the iris and is vulnerable to disruption following blunt trauma to the eye.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with diabetes presents with an acute onset of severe headache; a droopy right eyelid; and an inability to elevate, adduct, and depress the right eye. The right pupil appears dilated compared with the left pupil. The left eye shows no motility deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute third-nerve palsy secondary to intracranial aneurysm

options.label: B
options.text: Acute third-nerve palsy secondary to diabetic microvascular infarct

questions.correct_answer: A. Acute third-nerve palsy secondary to intracranial aneurysm
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute third-nerve palsy secondary to an intracranial aneurysm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An acute third-nerve palsy with pupil involvement and a severe headache should raise suspicion for an intracranial aneurysm, which requires immediate evaluation and treatment due to the risk of rupture.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of redness, light sensitivity, and episodic pain in the right eye. The patient has been using topical gentamicin eye drops for 7 days, which has not relieved any of his symptoms. His past medical history is significant for sarcoidosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Toxic conjunctivitis secondary to gentamicin use

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior uveitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anterior uveitis is often associated with autoimmune conditions, such as sarcoidosis, and presents with circumciliary redness, photophobia, and pain. Circumciliary congestion (intense redness around the limbus) is a distinguishing feature of anterior uveitis compared to other types of eye inflammation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents to the emergency clinic complaining of pain and redness in the right eye on awakening. He has no history of any sexually transmitted diseases. The patient admits to regularly wearing his soft contact lens while sleeping. Slit lamp examination reveals significant conjunctival injection and discharge. Fluorescein staining shows a large oval defect in the central cornea with an underlying white haze (Figure 3). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)  Bacterial keratitis (corneal ulcer)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacterial keratitis is a serious eye infection that often affects contact lens wearers, especially those who wear lenses overnight. Key features include pain, conjunctival injection, discharge, and a corneal infiltrate with an epithelial defect. Immediate treatment with intensive topical antibiotics is essential to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: A 65-year-old Asian woman awakens in the middle of the night with severe left eye pain associated with nausea and vomiting. On presentation to the emergency department, visual acuity is noted to be "counting fingers at 1 foot" in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. The left eye is very injected and the cornea appears hazy. The left pupil shows minimal reaction to light and appears slightly dilated. The right eye is completely normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Corneal abrasion secondary to recurrent corneal erosion

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute angle-closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute angle-closure glaucoma is a medical emergency characterized by sudden, severe eye pain, nausea, vomiting, and vision loss, often with a hazy cornea and a mid-dilated pupil. Immediate treatment is required to lower intraocular pressure, followed by definitive treatment with laser iridotomy.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of legal blindness in the United States in patients over the age of 65?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Age-related macular degeneration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Age-related macular degeneration is the most common cause of legal blindness in individuals over the age of 65 in the United States, primarily affecting central vision and making tasks requiring fine detail more challenging.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient who underwent perimetry had the following visual field defect. What is the site of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bitemporal hemianopia, caused by a lesion at the optic chiasm, is commonly due to compression from a pituitary tumor or other sellar region masses. Binasal hemianopia is a rare finding that may also indicate lateral compression of the chiasm, though it is far less common.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute vision loss and painful eye movements in one eye. Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the affected eye, while the optic disk appears normal. Visual field testing reveals a central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Optic neuritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Optic neuritis should be suspected in patients with acute, painful vision loss in one eye, a central scotoma, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and a normal-appearing optic disk. It is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis and requires further neurological evaluation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High hypermetropia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with advanced cataracts, visual disturbances (like erythropsia and cyanopsia) and altered Purkinje images often indicate high hypermetropia due to lens opacity and thickening. This can be confirmed by retinoscopy, which typically reveals a hypermetropic shift.

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden decrease in vision in right eye. While assessing his pupils, when light was shone in the left eye, both pupils constricted and when light was shown in the right eye, both pupils dilated. The likely abnormality is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marcus Gunn pupil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Marcus Gunn pupil (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) is detected using the swinging flashlight test, where the affected eye shows reduced constriction or even dilation in response to light due to an impaired afferent pathway. This finding often points to an optic nerve lesion.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Angular conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Angular conjunctivitis is a localized infection at the corners of the eyes caused by Moraxella axenfeld . Treatment typically includes zinc oxide and oxytetracycline ointments.

questions.text: The ophthalmic surgical instrument shown in the figure is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chalazion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The chalazion clamp is a specialized instrument used in the surgical treatment of chalazion to provide stabilization and minimize bleeding during incision and drainage.

questions.text: The Fovea centralis is responsible for the visual acuity of a person. How much is it’s diameter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1.5 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diameter of the fovea centralis is approximately 1.5 mm, which is the same size as the optic disc.

questions.text: The following finding is noted in a patient. What is the reason behind this pattern of deposition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased affinity to endothelium in inferior cornea

options.label: D
options.text: Lipophilic nature of the suspended particles

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Convection currents

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triangular pattern of corneal deposits in conditions like anterior uveitis is due to convection currents in the aqueous humor, directing particles to the inferior cornea, forming Arlt’s triangle.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with myopia started using her elder sister’s contact lenses. This sharing of contact lens may lead to the spread of which of the following infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sharing contact lenses can increase the risk of Acanthamoeba keratitis, a serious eye infection that can lead to corneal ulcers and vision loss. Proper contact lens hygiene and individual use are essential to prevent this infection.

questions.text: What is the most common cause for the appearance shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of leukocoria (white pupil reflex) in a child is retinoblastoma, characterized by a non-uniform appearance with possible calcifications. Early detection is critical for successful treatment and vision preservation.

questions.text: A child presents with proptosis, pain and Loss of vision. O/E the following picture is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Orbital cellulitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital cellulitis is a serious orbital infection characterized by proptosis, pain, and potential vision loss. Prompt treatment is essential to prevent complications.

questions.text: The nerve placed outside the muscle cone is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trochlear nerve (IV) is the only cranial nerve that innervates an extraocular muscle from outside the muscle cone, specifically supplying the superior oblique muscle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to your clinic with complaints of gradual blurring of vision over the past year. Upon examination, you notice a distortion of the corneal reflex at the center of the cornea, along with thinning of the cornea in the center. There is evidence of Munson's sign. Which of the following findings would you expect in the refractive error of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myopic refractive error

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keratoconus often leads to myopic refractive error due to the increased curvature and thinning of the cornea, which causes light to focus in front of the retina. Irregular astigmatism may also develop, but myopia is commonly the primary refractive change.

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstream of the management of Trachoma. What does the S in the acronym represent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "S" in the WHO SAFE strategy for trachoma stands for Surgery , which addresses advanced trachoma cases, particularly those with trichiasis to prevent vision loss.
  • ➤ Surgery

questions.text: The 68-year-old female patient has had a diabetic cataract for 3 months. Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sorbitol + Fructose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In diabetic cataracts, the accumulation of sorbitol and fructose in the lens, resulting from the polyol pathway, causes osmotic stress and lens opacity.
  • ➤ sorbitol
  • ➤ fructose

questions.text: Cornea reached adult size at ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cornea reaches its adult size, approximately 11.5 to 11.7 mm horizontally and 11 mm vertically, by 2 years of age .
  • ➤ 2 years of age

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of decreased vision and distortion in her left eye for the past few months. Upon further examination, you notice a bulging area in the posterior pole of the left eye, along with thinning of the sclera. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) confirms the presence of posterior staphyloma. Visual acuity in the left eye is 20/80. Intraocular pressure is within normal limits, and there are no signs of retinal detachment or other complications. In which of the following conditions the given scenario is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior staphyloma, characterized by bulging and scleral thinning at the posterior pole, is typically seen in pathologic myopia and can lead to decreased vision and visual distortion.
  • ➤ pathologic myopia

questions.text: Oldest fibres in lens are present in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Centre

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oldest fibers in the lens are found in the center (nucleus), while the newest fibers are located in the outermost, more superficial layers.
  • ➤ center

questions.text: Staphylococcus is associated with all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VKC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus is not associated with Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKOPTION C. , as VKC is primarily an allergic condition (Type I hypersensitivity) rather than a bacterial infection.
  • ➤ Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKOPTION C.

questions.text: Extraocular muscles are originated by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mesoderm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The extraocular muscles are derived from the mesoderm , while neuroectoderm and neural crest cells contribute to various other ocular structures.
  • ➤ mesoderm

questions.text: Volume of posterior segment is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4 ml

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior segment of the eye has a volume of 4 ml .
  • ➤ posterior segment
  • ➤ 4 ml

questions.text: Chalazion is:

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic granulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic non granulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland

options.label: D
options.text: Acute granulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland

questions.correct_answer: A. Chronic granulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous inflammation of meibomian gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chalazion is characterized by chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland, resulting in a painless, firm eyelid lump.

questions.text: Aqueous as compared to plasma has all more, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Higher glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aqueous humor has lower glucose compared to plasma, while it has higher concentrations of ascorbate, lactate, and pyruvate.

questions.text: Muscle inserted farthest from limbus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) SR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Superior Rectus muscle is inserted farthest from the limbus, at approximately 7.7 mm.
  • ➤ Mnemonics:
  • ➤ Mnemonics:
  • ➤ MILs (Mother-In-Laws) - To remember the sequence from closest to farthest: M edial, I nferior, L ateral, S uperior
  • ➤ MILs (Mother-In-Laws)
  • ➤ M
  • ➤ I
  • ➤ L
  • ➤ S

questions.text: A 15 years old boy presents to a clinic with difficulty in coordination of movements and abdominal pain. On further examination copper deposition in a ring form is seen in cornea. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wilson’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson's disease can cause copper deposition in the cornea, forming a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring. This disease results from impaired copper metabolism, leading to neurological and hepatic symptoms .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor in the prevention of endophthalmitis in cataract surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most effective preventive measure against endophthalmitis in cataract surgery is preoperative preparation with povidone iodine, which significantly reduces ocular surface bacterial load .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Economic blindness is defined when visual acuity falls below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6/60

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Economic blindness is defined when an individual's visual acuity falls below 6/60, affecting their ability to perform tasks that require distance vision and impacting their economic productivity .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ WHO Classification of Visual Impairment and Blindness
  • ➤ WHO Classification of Visual Impairment and Blindness
  • ➤ Mnemonic for Visual Impairment Classification: "LESMA"
  • ➤ L – Low Vision E – Economic Blindness (6/60) S – Social Blindness (3/60) M – Manifest Blindness (1/60) A – Absolute Blindness (No Light Perception)
  • ➤ L – Low Vision
  • ➤ L
  • ➤ E – Economic Blindness (6/60)
  • ➤ E
  • ➤ S – Social Blindness (3/60)
  • ➤ S
  • ➤ M – Manifest Blindness (1/60)
  • ➤ M
  • ➤ A – Absolute Blindness (No Light Perception)
  • ➤ A

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient visits the clinic complaining of intermittent blurry vision and mild eye discomfort. Upon examination, you notice cupping of the optic nerve head and visual field loss. Which clinical finding represents the earliest manifestation of chronic simple glaucoma in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Scotoma in Bjerrums area

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest visual field defect in chronic simple glaucoma is a scotoma in Bjerrum's area. Visual field loss progresses in stages, eventually leading to tunnel vision in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents after 3 days of cataract surgery with history of pain and decrease in vision after an initial improvement. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endophthalmitis should be suspected in any patient who presents with pain and decreased vision within a few days of cataract surgery, especially if there was initial improvement in vision followed by a rapid decline.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of hyper­mature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photo­phobia, blurring of vision and on exami­nation has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by leakage of lens proteins through an intact capsule in a hypermature cataract, causing deep anterior chamber, ciliary congestion, and increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A woman presents to you complaining of a red, watering eye for the past two days with stinging and some photophobia. Her vision has dropped slightly to 20/30. She has a history of diabetes and taking drops for glaucoma, but is otherwise healthy. The most likely cause of her redness is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Viral conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of a red, watering eye with mild photophobia and slight vision loss, especially without severe pain, is viral conjunctivitis, commonly adenoviral conjunctivitis with possible keratitis involvement .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In which condition is collagen cross-linking used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Keratoconus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Collagen cross-linking (C3R) is specifically indicated for keratoconus to strengthen and stabilize the cornea, preventing further progression of the disease.
  • ➤ keratoconus

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle which does not arise from the apex of the orbit is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inferior oblique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior oblique muscle is the only extraocular muscle that does not originate from the orbital apex. It arises from the medial wall near the anterior part of the orbital floor.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with complaints of blurry vision after cataract surgery. Fundus fluorescein angiography reveals a characteristic 'flower petals' appearance in the macula region. What is he MOST likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystoid macular edema (CME) is identified by the 'flower petals' or petaloid appearance on fundus fluorescein angiography and is commonly managed with corticosteroids or NSAIDs.

questions.text: A 39 year old woman presents with complains of a six month history of amenorrhea, galactorrhoea and an increasingly severe frontal headache. On further questioning she has had several near misses while driving recently but denies any visual problems. She has no past medical or surgical history and takes no regular medicines. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband and works as a teacher. She is happy in her work and not stressed. Neurological examination reveals a visual field defect but is otherwise normal.Given the likely diagnosis, which visual field defect is expected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bitemporal hemianopia is the characteristic visual field defect seen in patients with pituitary adenomas pressing on the optic chiasm, often presenting with peripheral vision loss .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of discharge, pain, and redness in his left eye. He states that his ophthalmologist surgically placed a "filter" in this eye 5 years ago to control his glaucoma. Visual acuity is 20/200 in this eye. Inspection reveals a very injected and swollen eye. You also note a very milky layer of fluid accumulating in the anterior chamber (Figure). What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis caused by neisseria gonorrhea

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bacterial endophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacterial endophthalmitis, especially in the delayed-onset form, is a potential complication of glaucoma filtering surgery. It presents with pain, redness, reduced vision, and a hypopyon in the anterior chamber .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: The finding that all three types of Duane’s syndrome share is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Globe retraction with adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The defining feature that all types of Duane's syndrome share is globe retraction with adduction, due to co-contraction of the medial and lateral rectus muscles .
  • ➤ Duane's syndrome share is globe retraction
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Where does the marked muscle originate f
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Annulus of Zinn

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The annulus of Zinn, or common tendinous ring, serves as the origin for all four rectus muscles (superior, inferior, medial, and lateral) of the eye.

questions.text: What is the correct order of insertion of muscles from near to far from the limbus?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Medial rectus > Inferior rectus

options.label: B
options.text: Medial rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Inferior rectus

options.label: C
options.text: Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: Superior rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Medial rectus

questions.correct_answer: C. Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of insertion of the rectus muscles from near to far from the limbus is Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus (MILS) .
  • ➤ Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus (MILS)

questions.text: A value of 0.75D was deduced from the retinoscopy reading as a part of drug correction. The likely drug used was?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cyclopentolate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For retinoscopy readings showing mild residual accommodation, Cyclopentolate is a common choice for partial cycloplegia, yielding accurate results for refractive correction.
  • ➤ Cyclopentolate

questions.text: Presbyopia is due to
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbyopia is caused by a combination of factors, including the loss of elasticity of the lens, weakness of the ciliary muscles, and weakening of the suspensory ligaments, making "All of the above" the correct answer.

questions.text: Contraindication to LASIK
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Keratoconus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keratoconus is an absolute contraindication for LASIK due to the risk of worsening corneal instability.

questions.text: Paton's line is seen in
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Papilledema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paton's lines are seen in papilledema and are indicative of increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-year-old child with cataract for second opinion. The child appears othrotropic and fine. What will be the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cataract surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a 3-year-old child with cataract, cataract surgery is the appropriate management to ensure proper visual development and prevent amblyopia.

questions.text: In trachoma the patient is infectious when there is:

options.label: D
options.text: Follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.

questions.correct_answer: D. Follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In trachoma, a patient is infectious during the active stage, characterized by follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.

questions.text: In grades of binocular vision what the encircled figure denote:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The encircled figure represents fusion , the second grade of binocular vision, where two images are merged into one cohesive perception.
  • ➤ fusion

questions.text: Dense scar of cornea with incarceration of iris is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adherent Leucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An adherent leucoma is a dense scar on the cornea with incarceration or attachment of the iris.

questions.text: A young male presents with central scotoma in the left eye. His right eye showed 6/6 vision though with metamorphopsia. On examination there is focal foveal detachment in the left eye. What should be the next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Inquire about trauma to the other eye

questions.correct_answer: B. Inquire about use of steroids
questions.explanation:
Ans. B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR) is associated with corticosteroid use, and in cases of central scotoma and foveal detachment, inquiring about steroid use is a critical next step.

questions.text: Amongst which of the following conditions is Patching of the eye contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mucopurulent conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patching of the eye is contraindicated in mucopurulent conjunctivitis because it promotes a moist environment that can worsen the infection.

questions.text: A female patient 18 years old, who is contact lens wearer since two years, is complaining of redness, lacrimation and foreign body sensation of both eyes. On examination, visual acuity was 6/6 with negative fluorescein test. The expected diagnosis can be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis (GPC) is a common diagnosis in contact lens wearers experiencing redness, lacrimation, and foreign body sensation, especially with a negative fluorescein test indicating no corneal damage.

questions.text: Evisceration is:

options.label: B
options.text: Excision of all the inner contents of the eyeball including the uveal tissue

questions.correct_answer: B. Excision of all the inner contents of the eyeball including the uveal tissue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Excision of all the inner contents of the eyeball including the uveal tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evisceration involves the excision of all inner contents of the eyeball, including the uveal tissue, while preserving the scleral shell and extraocular muscles.

questions.text: Koeppe’s nodules are found in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Iris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koeppe’s nodules are found on the iris, particularly in cases of granulomatous uveitis, at the pupillary margin.

questions.text: Phacolytic glaucoma is best treated by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cataract extraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best treatment for phacolytic glaucoma is cataract extraction, which directly removes the cause of the increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: You have been referred a case of open angle glaucoma. Which of the following would be an important point in diagnosing the case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Optic disc cupping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Optic disc cupping is a critical feature in diagnosing open-angle glaucoma, reflecting the characteristic optic nerve damage associated with this condition.

questions.text: Primary optic atrophy results from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neurological disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary optic atrophy typically results from neurological disease affecting the optic nerve directly, without preceding swelling or inflammation of the optic disc.

questions.text: A one-month old baby is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Buphthalmos

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An enlarged cornea with photophobia and tearing in an infant suggests buphthalmos, a form of congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: Herpes simplex keratitis is characterized by:

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of pus in the anterior chamber

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Corneal hyposthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes simplex keratitis is characterized by corneal hyposthesia (reduced corneal sensation), a key diagnostic feature.
